text: hi everyone my name is victoria i'm an engineering manager at deliveroo
deliverer for those of you that don't know is a food tech company we feed hungry customers around the
world in 13 markets if you think that it is your pm's job
to know what stakeholders want or what customers need you're wrong if you think that as a
software engineer your sole responsibility it is to write software according to specifications
and everything else is faff you're wrong
and if you think that it is someone else's job perhaps a manager's job
to make your team great you're wrong again so for that reason stick with me for the
next about 30 minutes and hear me talking about a case study
um about a group of engineers and data scientists that worked together for about a year
and became a high performing team by embracing change improving their daily
practices and overcoming a lot of communication challenges together
before i dive deeper into my story please let me set the scene and give you some useful
context i joined the company as a software engineer
a year later i transitioned into a new role and i became an engineering manager i
had a very smooth transition into my role i was lucky i still call my first team a
happy bubble disappointingly this talk is not about happy bubbles
it is about the next team i took on so the team was a smart bunch of
well-seasoned engineers and data scientists we had a product manager the team also
shared their engineering manager and their data science manager with a few other teams
which is why i was very excited to the opportunity to step in and dedicate my full time to that
team i also have to say that there was a perception about that team that it was a bit
sluggish lacking drive and somewhat had strong
that team had a track record of using machine learning to build their products
i will refer to machine learning as models or algorithms in my talk
so the team has just finished building and releasing a bunch of very sophisticated models to
production and they were ready to pivot in order to help the company
with one of the most anticipated objectives for the year which was profitable sustainable growth
through new pricing quickly so let me explain
for customers that ordered food we used to charge a flat fee as a
delivery fee so if alice the customer wanted to order
a chicken wing from a shop downstairs she had to pay 2 pounds 50 in delivery fee
if she wanted to order 15 pizzas for her birthday party or something from her favorite italian restaurant
which was five miles away we would charge her the same amount as delivery fee two pounds fifty
and equivalent mountain all countries we operated in now this is suboptimal from many points
of view and what we had to do is to find a way to charge customers a variable fee but make it work for the
company on the other hand every order it is
delivered to you by a writer we used to have a very very simple
formula to calculate the price which we would offer on a per-order basis to our writers now
if bob the rider was asked to deliver the chicken wing from downstairs and he was
nearby we would pay him a certain amount and if we ask
him to deliver the 15 pizzas he had to cycle five miles away get the
pizzas on his back so back perhaps on the hill and we would pay him a similar amount
now you can clearly see how bob might be pissed off so we had to find a way to pay our
riders in a smarter transparent and sustainable way
now why was this all very important for the company we operate in a hugely hugely
complicated market where we have a lot of competition so if we don't adapt quickly to the
ever-changing environment we're dead i mean
like not dead that but as a company we're dead so this is how that team became to be
the pricing team
when i joined the team when i joined the team i allowed myself some time to observe
so i wanted to see a few things first of all i wanted to see what is it
that we're building we had to come up with some brand new models perhaps very smart ones
and i wanted to see what was the ideation session like how did we go about thinking
as a team about the products we're going to build i wanted to see how the team works as an
entity i wanted to see how engineers and data scientists work together
i wanted to see how the team interacts with the outside world with other teams with stakeholders
and ultimately i wanted to know my reports i didn't work with them before that so i had to
know them i wanted to see what were their contributions towards our projects and ultimately how their
individual works rolled up into helping the company grow
so i thought that we
had to pick up momentum and because we wanted to deliver things pretty quickly we had to change a few
things in a way i thought to myself if i tell people
that we all wanted to be successful we all wanted to deliver those projects and
everything is going to be great people would be on board and there were
except the change part so nobody
really pushed back but nobody jumped out of joy either so i thought
i'll just start with little things and it'll be fine
so our team came up with this idea of using a random forest
for one of our algorithms now i was as confused as some of you now
when i've heard about the random forest so i went on to do some research and reading and educate myself about it
apparently it is a fancy regression but i still didn't understand how that
fits our project and if i didn't understand i was part of
the team with the team every day and if i didn't get what is it that my team is building
how are they doing it can you imagine how hard it was for the rest of the business to understand it
i mean how are we going to charge customers according to what principles how are we going to pay

so perhaps improving our product algorithm and engineering specifications
was a great way to help with that so that at any point in time if anyone
in the business wanted to know what is going on and how are we thinking about the new product
they could have a plain easy answer at the team level some
common agile practices existed but they weren't very efficient so stand-ups were free form they were
totally optional for managers i don't think any manager has ever showed up until i
joined uh team plannings existed there were an hour or an hour and a half long
meetings about what uh color our jira epic should be
people worked on stuff the priority and importance of the stuff
was not super clear and even if an engineer and a data scientist worked

is so many easy wins we can have and let's just get it over the line and move
on at individual level people were
in principle used to have one-to-ones but as i mentioned they were used to a

of having a regular session with each other great
so a few changes in a few ideas i still had in my mind about improvements it was the

a two hours long retro to hear about how disruptive the changes were
how inconvenient and annoying it was to come to stand up every day
as early as 10 a.m and why would managers need to know
all those details how algorithms work how services are going to change i mean why do they care don't they need
to go to meetings don't they have stakeholders to touch base with
i was not prepared and after that retro i locked myself in the
room and i cried for an hour where's the um thank you
um yes so a month in
not much progress on the projects at all and a serious slap to my manager's face
got me thinking how can i fix what i've started and how can we get on the project
finally i started honing my relationships with
my fellow team leaders the product manager and the data science manager
the good news was that we were aligned about how we want to work together and
what we wanted for the team i still needed to know if things

so i had to know if the team had a problem to begin with and so i needed to know what
is it that we're doing and how are we doing it and i needed to know the details i needed to understand them
in order to do my job properly
for that i treated the unknowns that i had as black boxes
so i started by questioning what is it that we're building what is the
components that we're working on what are they going to do what are their inputs and outputs and
things started to clarify we had to spot complexities
and challenge the team to cut down on the complexities because we wanted to move fast
i clearly have not done a good job of explaining why i'm introducing change i didn't
articulate very well how important it was for the company to get those projects done
and done on time so i fixed that and as an additional help i
worked with my fellow team leaders to recognize and thank people that were
adopting new ways of working and that weren't that resistant to change and most importantly
that had constructive feedback about how we're working and about all the changes
the ugly news was that my report still didn't understand what my responsibilities and
accountabilities were for a very good reason i never told them
so we started working on that i was very explicit about what my role was but by far the most
complicated conversation i had was with my team lead
in the end he asked me why was i assigned to the team because
everything was working fine i mean why'd you have a full-time manager
it was great before i joined so i had to be very transparent and
honest with him i did say that our senior leadership didn't have trust that our team could
deliver those projects on time and boom it clicked in his hat why i cared
why we have so many questions why we had to keep the business up to date
great so a few a few weeks in again and the team picked up some steam we had
pretty good momentum we were clear about what we're building
small features started to see the light of production and we were finally ready to test
our models for the first time for the consumer pricing model we
decided to test it in the uk our biggest market before releasing it before trying it on
we looked at the data we wanted to make sure that our customers paid the same on average the data looked
absolutely fine we only had the small percentage of outliers but we were not alarmed at all
nobody cares about outliers so the big day we released the model we turned it on
and within less than a day our stakeholders come back to us
absolutely pissed off some customers had to pay as much as
three times more than they used to our stakeholders absolutely did not buy
our outliers thing where we saw a small percentage of data that was just
not fitting the the overall story they saw customers that had to pay
more than they used to and they were never going to come back to us so the model was unacceptable
on the rider's side we were a lot more careful we thought to find a tiny tiny area
in the uk where we could test our model so we found a really small area with a
handful of riders and we turned the model on
after one hour and about maybe 10 orders placed
riders went on strike
so our riders are very knowledgeable about areas where they typically work
they deliver usually from the same restaurants typically to the same customers
so they're used to seeing certain numbers in their app they used to be paid
certain money even if they earned in that hour when the model
was on they earned slightly more than they typically would
and we compared this data with same riders a week ago same day same same hour of
day everything uh very equivalent they earned slightly more but they hated
the change they hated the change too i mean how ironic that could be
so we had to turn it back off again
the ugly news was that clearly we didn't know our stakeholders and more than that
remember in the uk we charged a few customers slightly more
and slightly more three times more all other countries that knew about this
experiment did not want to participate anymore until we proved that our model was bulletproof
so we didn't know our stakeholders and that was a very bad situation in
we were lucky to be given a second chance our senior leadership trusted us to do it again
but it was very clear to us that we don't have a third try
we had a very fixed deadline to deliver those changes by we had to pull up our
songs or we didn't have a team
so the bad news was that the previous iteration our first trial highlighted that we had a lot of
complexity in our processes and in our code basis
for random forest anyone hello remembers so we had to move fast we had a fixed
deadline we had to come up with a way to deliver
those models according to the expectations and get them right
we had to be creative because we didn't have enough data scientists to work on those models in parallel
i looked at other teams in the company that perhaps had similar issues in the past but none
of them had the issue of not having enough key people in the team to deliver those projects
i mean hiring is an option of course but we will never have the luxury of time to onboard those people and
and get the work done on time so we had to find a different way
one crazy idea came up to my mind what if we ask engineers to do some of the
things that typically a data scientist would do they were extremely smart people they
knew a lot of things already and they were willing to help their colleagues that were under a lot of stress
so we gave it a go we looked at the some of the things that
data scientists did and some of the models that this team has produced in the past
had a few components that were sort of part of the process all the time so we
had to come up with a data set it's a very typical component in
in teams that do use machine learning to build their products our models had a few steps
like training like data extraction things like that
and we also had a pipeline that it all that stitched all those all of those components together so when
we took a closer look at things we figured that the data set is nothing
else other than sql the model was python the steps for the model were
python as well the pipeline was just scripting
so the bulk of the work was coding and engineers are brilliant
at reading and writing code they do that for profit
i mean i'm speaking to converter but yes um so when we poked at the at the data
science backlog we we realized that we can share the majority of the work and we could allow
our data scientists to do the things only a data scientist could do and share
everything else so the pace started to go up massively
and we quickly picked up a lot of the things
the good news was that a real bonus uh and one amazing thing that happened
when engineers started punking around the data science code bases was that they started applying best engineering
practices to those code bases they added tests they added linting they added
a few other tools to to help with like speeding up the pipeline and stuff like
that a few other useful things started to emerge some guidelines guidelines on how to
write better sequel how to write it so that the next person doesn't pull up their hair
a guideline on how to modularize um the the data science code bases i mean
there are code bases there it's code you can you can apply the same principles to to most of
the code anyway we introduced the the code review
process that didn't exist between data sciences and that's good
and one of the biggest artifacts that we produced was a machine learning readiness exercise
which is essentially a checklist of things to do before or after releasing
a major version of an algorithm or a brand new algorithm and this exercise is widely used by
all of our teams that deliver that use machine learning to build their products
another good thing that happened for individuals in that team was that they've learned a huge amount in that
year we started working together a lot better
we haven't even realized that we had such a barrier between engineers and data scientists we never
assumed that that we could do each other's work or we can help each other
so finally the walls that we didn't even know that existed broke down there was no more black magic
uh concept around what data scientists are doing
as a result no other iteration that we released on the models made writers to go on
strike we've never charged customer crazy delivery fees anymore
and i'm very proud to tell you that a lot of those people were promoted
and i'm very very glad to be working with them because they're extremely smart and they worked extremely hard
and they were rewarded for it
so what are the some of the takeaways that i wanted you to to know and think about at the product
level first of all know who your stakeholders are think how they think give them what they
need you can have the most pristine and ideal code base
but if the product doesn't do what the customer needs it has no value
start from the first principles find out where you can cut out on that complexity random forest
again so if you fail faster you'll learn
faster what is the right product what is the right approach and you'll ultimately get to the results
that you wanted a lot quicker than you can expect
for teams a team an efficient team is a lot more than

so remember that and for individuals
don't think that people will know what you're doing as you may not

explain that to them your manager is not here to annoy you

just ask them i mean they'll gladly say it to you i'm sure embrace

because it will happen with or without you is the law of nature
